title: Contrast: Although / In spite of / However

questions.question: ___ it was raining, we went for a walk.
In spite of ___ tired, he continued working.
questions.explanation: After 'in spite of' we use a noun or gerund (-ing form).

questions.question: He studied a lot. ___, he didn’t pass the test.
questions.explanation: 'However' is used at the beginning of a contrast sentence.

questions.question: ___ her efforts, she failed the interview.
questions.explanation: 'In spite of' is followed by a noun or noun phrase.

questions.question: ___ she was tired, she kept running.
questions.explanation: 'Although' introduces a full clause with subject + verb.

questions.question: ___ the traffic, we arrived on time.
questions.explanation: 'Despite' is followed by a noun or gerund.

questions.question: They were late. ___, the meeting started on time.
questions.explanation: Used to contrast two separate sentences.

questions.question: ___ the cold weather, he wore only a T-shirt.
___ being young, she is very responsible.
questions.explanation: 'Despite' can be followed by a gerund.

questions.question: He didn’t win the race. ___, he was happy.
questions.explanation: 'However' introduces a contrast with the previous sentence.

questions.question: ___ the noise, I managed to sleep.
questions.explanation: 'Despite' is used with a noun or noun phrase.

questions.question: ___ she tried hard, she didn’t succeed.
He was hungry. ___, he didn’t eat.
___ being rich, he lives simply.
questions.explanation: 'In spite of' followed by gerund or noun.
